comments.body:
Hey @Ledragon, just stumbled upon the PR. A few days ago I started the updates but didn't realize that the PR was already created by you :) Thanks a lot for these updates.

A tiny suggestion if its okay: [here](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/47181/files#diff-e8b9f215cbab373580660b51a4326b3bR50) there are multiple variables which are already declared. Seems like we may not need to redeclare `mo` as `mixedObjectOrUndefined` can do the same task.

The hyperlink is supposed to point to:

![Screen Shot 2020-10-03 at 4 10 18 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25290212/94989508-fc3aad00-0592-11eb-9271-8fee18b04c98.png)
I'll approve this as is, but generally the way to verify types is to use `// $ExpectType`: https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/#linter

In some places `numOrUndefined` is used. Similarly, we also have [num](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/47181/files#diff-e8b9f215cbab373580660b51a4326b3bR42). Was thinking that we could possibly avoid redeclaring `minIndex` for consistency.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +214,218 @@
let minIndex: number = d3Array.minIndex([3, 3, 1, 1]); // 2
minIndex = d3Array.minIndex(["20", "3"]); // 0
minIndex = d3Array.minIndex([{ name: "Alice", age: 23 }, { name: "Bob", age: 32 }], d => d.age); // 0
// extent() --------------------------------------------------------------------

comments.body:
Had a small hunch that the following could be better since as per docs, the output of `.leastIndex` is a number.

```
num = d3Array.leastIndex(numbersArray);
```

For consistency, we could use:

```
num = d3Array.count([1, 2, NaN]); // 2
```

to avoid redeclaring a new variable.
